text: The question that I like to ask is, 'What could I do or stop doing that would make it easier to work with me?' But do not write down my question because if you sound like Kim Scott and not like yourself, then other people are not going to believe you want the answer. It needs to sound authentic to you.
speaker: Kim Scott
context: Lenny asks Kim about how to solicit feedback effectively from colleagues and employees. Kim explains that asking generic questions like 'Do you have any feedback for me?' is ineffective because people will just say everything is fine. She shares her go-to question but emphasizes that leaders must adapt the language to sound authentic to their own communication style, otherwise people won't believe they genuinely want honest feedback.
text_ko: 제가 자주 하는 질문은 "제가 뭘 더 하거나 멈추면 같이 일하기 더 쉬워질까요?"예요. 그런데 그 문장을 그대로 적어 두지는 마세요. 김 스콧처럼 말하면 당신답지 않게 들려서 사람들이 진심으로 답을 해주지 않을 거예요. 당신만의 말투로 진짜 자연스럽게 물어야 해요.
text_zh: 我喜欢问的一个问题是："我可以做什么，或者停止做什么，来让大家跟我合作起来更轻松？"不过别照搬我这个问题，因为如果你说话像金·斯科特(Kim Scott)而不像你自己，别人就不会相信你真的想听到答案。这话得从你嘴里说出来才有说服力。
text_es: La pregunta que me gusta hacer es: '¿Qué podría hacer o dejar de hacer para que sea más fácil trabajar conmigo?' Pero no te copies mi pregunta tal cual, porque si suenas como Kim Scott y no como tú mismo, la gente no va a creer que de verdad quieres saber la respuesta. Tiene que sonar auténtico, que suene a ti.
key_sentence: What could I do to make it easier to work with me sounds authentic.

text: If I march into a room and I say, 'Lenny, I'm going to tell you the truth.' I'm kind of implying I've got a pipeline to God and you don't know anything. And that's not what this is all about. This is a dialogue, not a monologue.
speaker: Kim Scott
context: Lenny asks Kim for specific language and phrases to use when giving direct feedback without making people defensive. Kim explains why she uses the term 'candor' instead of 'truth' when giving feedback. She emphasizes that effective feedback should be humble and conversational rather than authoritative, because claiming to know 'the truth' creates an adversarial dynamic instead of collaborative dialogue.
text_ko: 제가 방에 들어가서 '레니, 내가 진실을 말해줄게'라고 하면, 마치 제가 신과 직통으로 연결돼 있고 레니는 아무것도 모르는 사람인 것처럼 비춰져요. 그런데 그게 이 일의 취지가 아니에요. 이건 독백이 아니라 대화예요.
text_zh: 如果我走进房间就说，"小李，我来告诉你真相。"这样说话其实就是在暗示我掌握了绝对真理，而你什么都不懂。但事情不是这样的。我们要的是对话，不是一个人在那儿独白。
text_es: Si llego a una sala y le digo a Lenny, "Te voy a decir la verdad", como que estoy dando a entender que tengo línea directa con Dios y que tú no sabes nada. Y no se trata de eso. Esto es un diálogo, no un monólogo.
key_sentence: This is a dialogue, not a monologue, not a pipeline to God.

text: Six seconds is a really long time. Almost nobody can endure six full seconds of silence. So they'll probably tell you something. So now you've dragged this poor soul out on a conversational limb that they never wanted to go on.
speaker: Kim Scott
context: Kim is explaining her framework for soliciting feedback from colleagues and employees. After asking for feedback, she recommends counting to six seconds of silence to embrace the discomfort, because most people cannot tolerate that much silence and will eventually share something. She describes this as putting the other person in an uncomfortable but necessary position to get honest feedback.
text_ko: 여섯 초는 정말 긴 시간이에요. 거의 아무도 여섯 초 동안의 완전한 침묵을 견디지 못해요. 그래서 대부분 뭔가 말하게 돼요. 그렇게 하면 결국 상대를 원치 않았던 대화의 난처한 상황으로 끌어낸 셈이에요.
text_zh: 六秒钟其实挺长的。基本上没人能忍受整整六秒的沉默。所以他们多半会说点什么。这样一来，你就把这个可怜的家伙逼到了一个他们根本不想聊的话题上。
text_es: Seis segundos es muchísimo tiempo. Casi nadie aguanta seis segundos completos de silencio. Así que probablemente te van a decir algo. Y ahí ya tienes a esta pobre persona metida en una conversación que nunca quiso tener.
key_sentence: Silence can drag this poor soul out on a conversational limb.

text: A person takes a huge risk, especially if this person is your employee. A person takes a huge risk to give you critical feedback. And if you do not reward that risk richly, you're never going to get any feedback again.
speaker: Kim Scott
context: Kim is explaining the final step in her framework for soliciting feedback - the importance of rewarding candor. She emphasizes that when employees give their boss critical feedback, they're putting themselves in a vulnerable position that could potentially harm their career. Leaders must demonstrate appreciation and take action on the feedback to encourage future honest communication.
text_ko: 누군가, 특히 직원이 당신에게 중요한 피드백(critical feedback)을 주려면 큰 위험을 감수하는 거예요. 그 위험을 충분히 보상해주지 않으면 다시는 피드백을 받을 수 없을 거예요.
text_zh: 员工给你提尖锐意见，这其实是冒了很大风险的。如果你不好好回应这种勇气，以后就别想再听到什么真话了。
text_es: Cuando una persona se arriesga enormemente, sobre todo si es tu empleado, para darte feedback crítico o retroalimentación dura, y tú no valoras ese riesgo como se merece, puedes estar seguro de que nunca más vas a recibir ese tipo de comentarios honestos.
key_sentence: Reward that risk richly or lose future feedback.

text: We all behave like assholes sometimes. And it's a big problem for us as well as for the people around us. And here's my story, when I acted like a jerk, what's yours? And people, that kind of self-awareness, sometimes people talk about inflicted insight like it's some kind of burden, but usually that kind of self-awareness makes people feel lighter.
speaker: Kim Scott
context: Lenny asks Kim how to help leaders who have low self-awareness and believe obnoxious aggression is the only way to give feedback. Kim explains her approach of first sharing her own stories of when she made mistakes and acted poorly, then asking them for similar examples. This creates a safe space for self-reflection without judgment, helping leaders develop a growth mindset about their behavior.
text_ko: 우리 모두 가끔 정말 못되게 굴 때가 있어요. 그건 우리 자신에게도, 주변 사람들에게도 큰 문제예요. 제 얘기 하나 해볼게요 — 제가 못되게 굴었을 때가 있었어요. 여러분은 어때요? 사람들이 그런 자기 인식을 '강요된 깨달음(inflicted insight)'이라며 부담이라고 할 때도 있는데, 보통은 오히려 그런 자각 때문에 마음이 더 가벼워져요.
text_zh: 我们每个人有时候都会表现得很混蛋，这对我们自己和周围的人来说都是大问题。我来分享一下我当混蛋的经历，你们呢？你知道吗，这种自我认知，有些人觉得深刻的自省(inflicted insight)是种负担，但其实这种自我认知通常会让人感觉轻松很多。
text_es: Todos nos portamos como unos patanes a veces. Y es un gran problema tanto para nosotros como para la gente que nos rodea. Y aquí tienes mi historia, de cuando me comporté como un idiota, ¿cuál es la tuya? Y la gente, ese tipo de autoconocimiento, a veces hablan del insight doloroso como si fuera una carga, pero normalmente ese tipo de autoconocimiento hace que la gente se sienta más liviana.
key_sentence: Inflicted insight makes people feel lighter after acting like a jerk.

text: It's not disagreement that poses a risk to our relationships. It's unspoken disagreement. Many, I don't know about you Lenny, but a lot of my best professional relationships began with a good respectful disagreement.
speaker: Kim Scott
context: Kim is explaining how to handle feedback that you disagree with. She advises finding something you can agree with, then respectfully explaining your disagreement rather than just saying thank you and moving on. She makes the point that avoiding conflict by not voicing disagreements actually damages relationships more than having honest, respectful disagreements.
text_ko: 우리 관계를 위협하는 건 의견 차이 자체가 아니에요. 말로 꺼내지 않는, 즉 입밖으로 나오지 않은 의견 차이예요. 레니, 당신은 어떨지 모르겠지만 제 경험으론 가장 좋은 직장 관계들이 존중을 바탕으로 한 건설적인 의견 충돌에서 시작된 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 对我们关系构成威胁的不是意见分歧，而是那些憋在心里不说出来的分歧。我不知道你怎么样，Lenny，但我很多最好的职场关系都是从一次良性的、相互尊重的争论开始的。
text_es: No es el desacuerdo lo que pone en riesgo nuestras relaciones. Es el desacuerdo que nos callamos. Muchas de mis mejores relaciones profesionales, no sé si te pase igual Lenny, pero muchas empezaron con un buen desacuerdo respetuoso.
key_sentence: Unspoken disagreement poses a risk to our relationships, unlike respectful disagreement.
